awd_abstract_narration:
A request is made to fund Oceanographic Instrumentation on R/V Atlantic Explorer, a 168’ general purpose research vessel owned and operated by Bermuda Institute of Ocean Science (BIOS) as part of the United States Academic Research Fleet (ARF).  BIOS is a U.S. 501 (c) 3 and 509 (a) not-for-profit research and educational institution incorporated in the state of New York, and geographically located on the Island of Bermuda. The mission of the ship is to support funded science research throughout the Central Atlantic but specifically work in support of the Bermuda Atlantic Time-series (BATS) program. 

With this proposal, BIOS provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Instrumentation:

1)	LNP20 - Liquid Nitrogen Plant	$70,880
2)	WindSonic - Option 2, 2 x Multifunctional TFT Displays	$5,432
3)	SBE 32 Pylon, SBE43, SBE 38.		$34,871
4)	WET Labs C-Star Transmissometer (CST-25-PR), Flow Tube	$7,446
5)	Teledyne RDI Sentinel V100 300 Khz Real-Time ADCP	$31,001
6)	2 x MXO-4-Subconn-BIOS Rotocon Rotary Electrical Connectors 	$4,800
7)	Dragonfish, various cables and dummys 	$5,364
8)	2 x Peplink Balance 580 Mid-sized Business Router	$17,350
							$177,144
						IDC	$31,526
							$208,670

Broader Impacts
								
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The three major goals of the award were to acquire, install and operate the following ship-board systems for the R/V Atlantic Explorer.  

1. Liquid nitrogen plant for the R/V Atlantic Explorer. A constant supply of liquid nitrogen is critical to ensure samples are properly preserved, stored and shipped. Cryopreservation is used in many aspects of oceanographic research. This storage method has been used for marine cyanobacteria, bacterioplankton and pigments, picophytoplankton and virioplankton. The purchase and installation of a new liquid nitrogen plant for the ship to replace a failed system is a major goal of the award.

2. Teledyne RDI Sentinel V100 300 Khz Real-Time ADCP. The upgrade to the ADCP system is  important support for the measurements undertaken by ship users and projects such as BATS and Hydrostation S (e.g., Bates and Johnson, 2020, 2021). This also include data comparisons to the suite of Slocum gliders operated at BIOS (i.e., Ruth Curry, MAGIC laboratory). The purchase and installation of a new ADCP for the ship is the second major goal of the award.

3. SBE 32 Pylon, SBE43, SBE 38.  The SBE 32 Pylon is the vital part of the CTD it is releasing the 24 mounted bottles for water sampling.  

The achievements of the project were the successful acquisition, installation and operation of the following systems for the R/V Atlantic Explorer.

Liquid Nitrogen Generator. After a long lead time with production, the generator was commissioned in September 2023. Two of our technicians received hands on training by the manufacturer at their facility prior to delivery. So far in 2024, we have produced over 550L for scientists working on different NSF projects. All of these orders would have had to be shipped in from the US which is both costly and time consuming. Regular users have been trained to operate and dispense from the generator.

Hull mounted 300kHz ADCP. The ADCP was first installed in September 2023, however, a manufacturing defect resulted in instantaneous water ingress upon deployment. The unit was repaired under warranty, but that process took some time to complete. The unit was once again installed in June 2024 and has been in use on every cruise since. It has enabled the acquisition of higher resolution current data in the top 100m of the water column.

SBE 32 Pylon, SBE43, SBE 38: Water sampling sensors and instrumentation (SBE 32, 43 and 38). All sensors per the proposal were acquired and have entered service in our shared use equipment pool. Having a robust pool of sensors and instrumentation is critical to the science we undertake. Technicians have been training in the operations, maintenance and troubleshooting of these instruments.
